query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 Già era in loco onde s’udia ’l rimbombo 2 de l’acqua che cadea ne l’altro giro, 3 simile a quel che l’arnie fanno rombo,
4 quando tre ombre insieme si partiro, 5 correndo, d’una torma che passava 6 sotto la pioggia de l’aspro martiro.
query.result:
1 Already was in place where one heard the echo 2 of the water that fell into the other circle, 3 similar to that which the bees make rumble,
4 when three shadows together departed, 5 running, from a troop that was passing 6 under the rain of the harsh martyrdom.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
7 Venian ver’ noi, e ciascuna gridava: 8 «Sòstati tu ch’a l’abito ne sembri 9 esser alcun di nostra terra prava».
query.result: 7 They came toward us, and each one cried: 8 “Stop you who to the habit in me seem 9 to be someone from our land wicked.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
10 Ahimè, che piaghe vidi ne’ lor membri, 11 ricenti e vecchie, da le fiamme incese! 12 Ancor men duol pur ch’i’ me ne rimembri.
query.result: 10 Alas, what wounds I saw in their members, 11 recent and old, by the flames ignited! 12 Even less pain surely I remember them.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
13 A le lor grida il mio dottor s’attese; 14 volse ’l viso ver’ me, e «Or aspetta», 15 disse, «a costor si vuole esser cortese.

Please translate each line literally into English.
16 E se non fosse il foco che saetta 17 la natura del loco, i’ dicerei 18 che meglio stesse a te che a lor la fretta».
query.result: 16 And if it were not the fire that flashes 17 the nature of the place, I would say 18 that better it would be for you than for them the haste.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
19 Ricominciar, come noi restammo, ei 20 l’antico verso; e quando a noi fuor giunti, 21 fenno una rota di sé tutti e trei.
query.result: 19 To begin again, as we remained, and he 20 the ancient verse; and when they were come to us, 21 they made a wheel of themselves, all three.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 Qual sogliono i campion far nudi e unti, 23 avvisando lor presa e lor vantaggio, 24 prima che sien tra lor battuti e punti,
25 così rotando, ciascuno il visaggio 26 drizzava a me, sì che ’n contraro il collo 27 faceva ai piè continüo vïaggio.
query.result:
22 As champions are accustomed to go naked and oiled, 23 noticing their capture and their advantage, 24 before they are among them struck and pierced,
25 thus rotating, each one the face 26 directed towards me, so that against the neck 27 made to the feet continuous journey.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
28 E «Se miseria d’esto loco sollo 29 rende in dispetto noi e nostri prieghi», 30 cominciò l’uno, «e ’l tinto aspetto e brollo,
31 la fama nostra il tuo animo pieghi 32 a dirne chi tu se’, che i vivi piedi 33 così sicuro per lo ’nferno freghi.
query.result:
28 And “If the misery of this place alone 29 renders in spite us and our prayers,” 30 began one, “and the stained and murky appearance,
31 may our fame bend your soul 32 to tell who you are, that living feet 33 thus securely through hell deceive.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 Questi, l’orme di cui pestar mi vedi, 35 tutto che nudo e dipelato vada, 36 fu di grado maggior che tu non credi:
37 nepote fu de la buona Gualdrada; 38 Guido Guerra ebbe nome, e in sua vita 39 fece col senno assai e con la spada.
query.result:
34 These, the footprints of which you see me tread, 35 all though naked and peeled he goes, 36 was of a greater rank than you believe:
37 nephew he was of the good Gualdrada; 38 Guido Guerra he had as name, and in his life 39 he did with the intellect much and with the sword.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
40 L’altro, ch’appresso me la rena trita, 41 è Tegghiaio Aldobrandi, la cui voce 42 nel mondo sù dovria esser gradita.
query.result: 40 The other, who near me grinds the sand, 41 is Tegghiaio Aldobrandi, whose voice 42 in the world above should be pleasing.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
43 E io, che posto son con loro in croce, 44 Iacopo Rusticucci fui, e certo 45 la fiera moglie più ch’altro mi nuoce».
query.result: 43 And I, who am placed with them in cross, 44 Iacopo Rusticucci I was, and certainly 45 the fierce wife harms me more than anything else.

46 If I had been covered from the fire, 47 I would have thrown myself among them below, 48 and I believe that the doctor would have suffered it;
49 but because I would have been burned and cooked, 50 fear overcame my good will 51 that made me eager to embrace them.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 Poi cominciai: «Non dispetto, ma doglia 53 la vostra condizion dentro mi fisse, 54 tanta che tardi tutta si dispoglia,
55 tosto che questo mio segnor mi disse 56 parole per le quali i’ mi pensai 57 che qual voi siete, tal gente venisse.
query.result:
52 Then I began: “Not spite, but sorrow 53 your condition fixed within me, 54 so much that late it all strips itself,
55 as soon as this my lord said to me 56 words for which I thought to myself 57 that such people as you would come.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
58 Di vostra terra sono, e sempre mai 59 l’ovra di voi e li onorati nomi 60 con affezion ritrassi e ascoltai.
query.result: 58 Of your land I am, and always ever 59 the work of you and the honored names 60 with affection I traced and listened to.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 Lascio lo fele e vo per dolci pomi 62 promessi a me per lo verace duca; 63 ma ’nfino al centro pria convien ch’i’ tomi».

Please translate each line literally into English.
64 «Se lungamente l’anima conduca 65 le membra tue», rispuose quelli ancora, 66 «e se la fama tua dopo te luca,
67 cortesia e valor dì se dimora 68 ne la nostra città sì come suole, 69 o se del tutto se n’è gita fora;
70 ché Guiglielmo Borsiere, il qual si duole 71 con noi per poco e va là coi compagni, 72 assai ne cruccia con le sue parole».

Please translate each line literally into English.
73 «La gente nuova e i sùbiti guadagni 74 orgoglio e dismisura han generata, 75 Fiorenza, in te, sì che tu già ten piagni».
query.result: 73 “The new people and the sudden gains 74 have generated pride and excess, 75 Florence, so that you already have tears for it.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
76 Così gridai con la faccia levata; 77 e i tre, che ciò inteser per risposta, 78 guardar l’un l’altro com’ al ver si guata.

Please translate each line literally into English.
79 «Se l’altre volte sì poco ti costa», 80 rispuoser tutti, «il satisfare altrui, 81 felice te se sì parli a tua posta!
82 Però, se campi d’esti luoghi bui 83 e torni a riveder le belle stelle, 84 quando ti gioverà dicere “I’ fui”,
85 fa che di noi a la gente favelle».
query.result:
79 “If other times it costs you so little,” 80 responded all, “to satisfy others, 81 happy are you if you speak thus to your advantage!
82 Therefore, if you live out of these dark places 83 and return to see the beautiful stars, 84 when it will benefit you to say “I was,”
85 make that you speak of us to the people.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
86 Indi rupper la rota, e a fuggirsi 87 ali sembiar le gambe loro isnelle.
88 Un amen non saria possuto dirsi 89 tosto così com’ e’ fuoro spariti; 90 per ch’al maestro parve di partirsi.
query.result:
86 Then they broke the circle, and to flee 87 wings seemed their legs so swiftly.
88 A single amen could not have been said 89 sooner than they were vanished; 90 for to the master it seemed to depart.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
91 Io lo seguiva, e poco eravam iti, 92 che ’l suon de l’acqua n’era sì vicino, 93 che per parlar saremmo a pena uditi.
query.result: 91 I followed him, and we had not gone far, 92 that the sound of the water was so near, 93 that to speak we would be hardly heard.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
94 Come quel fiume c’ha proprio cammino 95 prima dal Monte Viso ’nver’ levante, 96 da la sinistra costa d’Apennino,
97 che si chiama Acquacheta suso, avante 98 che si divalli giù nel basso letto, 99 e a Forlì di quel nome è vacante,
100 rimbomba là sovra San Benedetto 101 de l’Alpe per cadere ad una scesa 102 ove dovea per mille esser recetto;
103 così, giù d’una ripa discoscesa, 104 trovammo risonar quell’ acqua tinta, 105 sì che ’n poc’ ora avria l’orecchia offesa.
query.result:
94 As that river which has its own course 95 first from Mount Viso towards the rising sun, 96 from the left coast of the Apennine,
97 which is called Acquacheta above, onward 98 before it spreads down into the low bed, 99 and at Forlì of that name is vacant,
100 thunders there over San Benedetto 101 of the Alps to fall at a descent 102 where it had to be received by a thousand;
103 thus, down from a sloping bank, 104 we found resounding that tinted water, 105 so that in a little while it would have offended the ear.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
106 Io avea una corda intorno cinta, 107 e con essa pensai alcuna volta 108 prender la lonza a la pelle dipinta.
query.result: 106 I had a rope around my waist, 107 and with it I thought at some time 108 to seize the lynx with the patterned skin.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 Poscia ch’io l’ebbi tutta da me sciolta, 110 sì come ’l duca m’avea comandato, 111 porsila a lui aggroppata e ravvolta.
query.result: 109 Afterwards, when I had it all unwound from me, 110 as the leader had commanded me, 111 I offered it to him, gathered and coiled.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
112 Ond’ ei si volse inver’ lo destro lato, 113 e alquanto di lunge da la sponda 114 la gittò giuso in quell’ alto burrato.
query.result: 112 And he turned towards the right side, 113 and somewhat from afar from the bank 114 he threw it down into that high whirlpool.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
115 ‘E’ pur convien che novità risponda’, 116 dicea fra me medesmo, ‘al novo cenno 117 che ’l maestro con l’occhio sì seconda’.
query.result: 115 “And it is necessary that a response be given,” 116 said I to myself, “to the new sign 117 that the master with the eye so follows.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
118 Ahi quanto cauti li uomini esser dienno 119 presso a color che non veggion pur l’ovra, 120 ma per entro i pensier miran col senno!
121 El disse a me: «Tosto verrà di sovra 122 ciò ch’io attendo e che il tuo pensier sogna; 123 tosto convien ch’al tuo viso si scovra».
query.result:
118 Ah, how cautious men ought to be, they say, 119 near to those who do not see the work itself, 120 but through thoughts look with understanding!
121 He said to me: “Soon will come from above 122 that which I await and which your thought dreams; 123 soon it must be revealed to your face.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
124 Sempre a quel ver c’ha faccia di menzogna 125 de’ l’uom chiuder le labbra fin ch’el puote, 126 però che sanza colpa fa vergogna;
127 ma qui tacer nol posso; e per le note 128 di questa comedìa, lettor, ti giuro, 129 s’elle non sien di lunga grazia vòte,
130 ch’i’ vidi per quell’ aere grosso e scuro 131 venir notando una figura in suso, 132 maravigliosa ad ogne cor sicuro,
133 sì come torna colui che va giuso 134 talora a solver l’àncora ch’aggrappa 135 o scoglio o altro che nel mare è chiuso,
136 che ’n sù si stende e da piè si rattrappa.
query.result:
124 Always to that truth which has a face of falsehood 125 the man should close his lips as long as he can, 126 because without fault it causes shame;
127 but here I cannot be silent; and by the notes 128 of this comedy, reader, I swear to you, 129 if they are not in vain of long grace,
130 that I saw through that thick and dark air 131 coming, noting, a figure above, 132 marvelous to every secure heart,
133 just as returns he who goes down 134 sometimes to loosen the anchor that grips 135 or rock or something else that is closed in the sea,
136 that upwards extends and from foot recovers itself.
